Why study animal guts? Because their microbial communities play a role in digestion. By learning more about how microbes assist in digestion, scientists could improve farm animals‚Äô ability to digest food and grow faster and stronger.

Because of the importance of digestion to growth, AAFC researchers are involved with several projects related to the microbiota in the guts of animals. Two are particularly interesting, because they focus on the guts of animals you might not think have much to do with agriculture: beavers and pandas. http://ow.ly/wxgU30fW2HS

caption_original:
Dr. Mary MacArthur carried out groundbreaking work in the field of food dehydration and freezing in the 1940s, a time when such technologies were of vital importance in support of war efforts in Europe. She carried out thousands of experiments at Ottawa‚Äôs Central Experimental Farm, largely using a large dehydration tunnel built in 1942. Her research greatly improved the appearance and nutritional value of commercial dehydrated vegetables.

A testament to her achievements, Dr. MacArthur was the first woman to be named as a Fellow of the Agriculture Institute of Canada.

Learn more about the latest research being carried out by AAFC scientists in the field of vegetable preservation. http://ow.ly/lsz630aLvfU

caption_original: One of the biggest challenges for Canadian apple producers is being able to predict exactly when fruit is ready for harvest. Our scientists in Summerland, BC and Kentville, NS are creating protocols for using the DA Meter, a new tool that takes the guesswork out of apple harvesting. This special tool helps fruit producers determine the ripeness of their crop, which helps ensure only the best apples make it to market. Check out our video to learn more about this process: #AppleMonth

caption_original:
Our potato genebank stores almost 180 potato varieties. These come from a wide range of countries beyond just Canada. From Ireland to Peru, there's a large amount of diversity in the samples we keep. This is a part of our commitment to global food security - the preservation of the global food supply. 

As our scientist Dr. Benoit Bizimungu explains, "There are many potato varieties that aren‚Äôt grown today with traits that are of current or future interest to researchers and educators. Preserving these varieties ensures valuable attributes, and even those with known susceptibility to certain diseases, are kept for the development of future, better varieties." ow.ly/I2Ru30ck05q

caption_original: Chemistry! Phosphorus is an essential element required by all living organisms, including the crops grown by Canadian farmers. It occurs naturally in soil when organic matter breaks down into its component parts. When crops need extra phosphorus farmers can apply it directly as a fertilizer. Learn how our researchers are getting a molecular view of how phosphorus moves through soils to help farmers decide where and when to add phosphorus for the best results and least impact on the environment:

caption_original: Almost hunted to extinction by the 1960s, wood bison were bred back to increase their numbers. Sadly, the sperm of the breeding animals also carried serious diseases. Using assisted reproductive technologies like cryopreservation, artificial insemination, and embryo transfer, our scientists and their peers at the Western College of Veterinary Medicine  in Saskatoon are helping both the bison population and the industry itself. Learn more about their work: http://ow.ly/wYcN305R6PO

Why study animal guts? Because their microbial communities play a role in digestion. By learning more about how microbes assist in digestion, scientists could improve farm animals‚Äô ability to digest food and grow faster and stronger.

Because of the importance of digestion to growth, AAFC researchers are involved with several projects related to the microbiota in the guts of animals. Two are particularly interesting, because they focus on the guts of animals you might not think have much to do with agriculture: beavers and pandas. http://ow.ly/hsQV30gBbvw

caption_original:
Join us at the Agassiz Research and Development Centre‚Äôs open house as we help the Agassiz Farms Cycle Tour celebrate its 10th anniversary. Explore the world of agriculture through a series of public presentations, interactive displays, hay wagon rides and fun activities for the whole family. You will have the opportunity to meet Agriculture and Agri-Food scientists first hand and learn more about local research being conducted to improve the farming sector.

Highlights include a kids‚Äô zone with fun activities featuring snail races, so bring the whole family and enjoy this day loaded with agricultural fun. In addition, there will be cake and ice cream at 11:00 a.m. and 1:00 p.m. The first 600 guests will receive tree seedlings on a first come, first served basis.

Free admission and parking - rain or shine.

caption_original: Wearing chemical resistant gloves and footwear can significantly reduce your exposure while handling pesticides. This special clothing or equipment (often called "PPE" for Personal Protective Equipment) is worn to minimize pesticide exposure and protect your health. This could include: chemical resistant unlined gloves and footwear, long-sleeved shirt and long pants, socks, or a respirator. Learn more about PPE from the Health Canada website: http://ow.ly/VxEc303xEWG

caption_original: The Supreme Court of Canada has ruled that there is an Aboriginal right to fish for food, social and ceremonial purposes. However, the buying, selling, trading, bartering or the offer to buy, sell, trade or barter Indigenous fishery resources harvested for food, social and ceremonial purposes is not permitted. Fishery Officers investigate any known or suspected incidents of persons engaging in illegal sale of fish and have authority under the Fisheries Act to fine or prosecute offenders.

However, the buying, selling, trading, bartering or the offer to buy, sell, trade or barter Indigenous fishery resources harvested for food, social and ceremonial purposes is not permitted. Fishery Officers investigate any known or suspected incidents of persons engaging in illegal sale of fish and have authority under the Fisheries Act to fine or prosecute offenders.

caption_original:
Over 5% of Canada‚Äôs oceans are now protected! We just reached and surpassed our national marine conservation target of protecting 5% of our marine and coastal areas by 2017 with the establishment of new marine refuges off the coast of British Columbia and Quebec. üåä
Over the past year we have made huge strides in ocean protection. Creating three new Marine Protected Areas, marine refuges, and identifying a new Area of Interest. We‚Äôre on track to meet our goal of protecting 10% of Canadian oceans by 2020. http://ow.ly/7ILY30gc6Mi

caption_original:
Effective immediately, vessels travelling in the western Gulf of St. Lawrence are mandated to reduce their speed to a maximum of 10 knots. The Government of Canada implemented the temporary mandatory slow-down for vessels longer than 20 metres in an effort to minimize risks to right whales in the area.

 
Following the recent whale deaths in the Gulf of St. Lawrence, we are making every effort possible to prevent further incidents and continue to work on the recovery of the species. We are awaiting results from the necropsies, and we have closed snow crab fishing to prevent entanglements.  Other fixed gear fisheries such as rock and toad crab fisheries have either been restricted to fish in shallow water or have had a delayed opening. For more information on our actions to date: http://ow.ly/n5qc30el2Kw

Transport and Infrastructure in Canada

We are awaiting results from the necropsies, and we have closed snow crab fishing to prevent entanglements. Other fixed gear fisheries such as rock and toad crab fisheries have either been restricted to fish in shallow water or have had a delayed opening. For more information on our actions to date: Transport and Infrastructure in Canada

caption_original:
8 million metric tonnes of plastic end up in the ocean every year, roughly the weight of sixty CN Towers. This plastic is ingested by marine animals and is responsible for the deaths of endangered species like the Leatherback turtle.
You can do your part in protecting our oceans and marine wildlife. Consider avoiding disposable items like plastic bags and using eco-friendly alternatives like reusable bags. Learn about other ways you can make an impact: http://ow.ly/brFA30e4WpZ

caption_original:
We all have a responsibility to protect and maintain our outdoors. Each year, Fishery Officers lay charges for illegal fishing, damage to fish habitat, polluting and disturbing marine mammals. If you witness a fisheries violation, please report it. You can contact our department directly by calling the local Fisheries and Oceans Canada office in your area: http://ow.ly/3T6P30fLWWR  

In any province or territory you can also call Crime Stoppers at 1-800-222-TIPS (8477) which is an anonymous service.

caption_original: Northern Snakehead is an invasive species that has not yet been found in any of Canada‚Äôs aquatic ecosystems, but we want to be on the lookout! Most snakehead species are native to warmer regions, but the Northern Snakehead occurs naturally in colder waters. Northern Snakehead can eat practically any small animal or fish they encounter. They can travel across land and live out of water for at least three days and reproduce quickly. If they find a way into natural freshwater ecosystems, they have the potential to cause serious damage to recreational and commercial fisheries. Report sightings: http://ow.ly/J8pb30gvleY

caption_original: Calling all Canadians, help the whales! Some of our whales are facing increased pressures from human activity. The Government of Canada is looking into how to recover the populations of three endangered whales: the Southern Resident Killer Whale, North Atlantic Right Whale and St. Lawrence Estuary Beluga. Have your say to help these whales. http://ow.ly/wOWz30egqmm

caption_original: Thanks to the Oceana Canada and DFO joint expedition, our researchers discovered previously unexplored areas of the Gulf of St. Lawrence. From August 23 to 30, the scientific team sampled and collected scientific data and filmed high-definition footage of the seafloor. Essential information on marine species living in surface waters, such as seabirds, sea turtles and sharks was also collected. This unique experience helped our scientists make major progress to document the richness of the marine environment. Valuable information that will help better protect it! Learn more about the expedition here: http://ow.ly/MLka30f0y6S

caption_original: Teamwork! The Canadian Coast Guard and our scientists work together to make science at sea happen. The Coast Guard recently deployed drifting buoys for our ocean research team while they were heading to the Arctic aboard the CCGS Terry Fox. Those buoys will transmit location data to help us understand ocean currents and to better forecast drifting icebergs, thus ensuring a safer navigation in the Arctic. http://ow.ly/LaPP30e3Laa

caption_original:
For the past two years, our team of Quebec biologists has been collecting data on artificial reefs developed for American lobster in the Magdalen Islands and the Gasp√© Peninsula. These 10m by 20m reefs are composed mainly of rocks of different sizes. They serve to offset the serious harm caused by marine environment projects by providing shelter and food for lobsters of all sizes. They become true nurseries for these crustaceans and are also, according to what the dives on the sites have shown, colonized by a wide variety of organisms.

Biologists now better understand the benefits of these developments to the surrounding environment and can make recommendations to developers to increase the stability of development over the longer term. Learn more about the Fisheries Protection Program: http://ow.ly/zFin30gNgIg

caption_original: If you‚Äôre landing at the wharf in St. Philip‚Äôs after you‚Äôve been out recreational cod fishing, go and introduce yourself to Sarah Quilty and Dylan Crichton. They‚Äôre two of the students DFO has hired for Citizen Cod 2017 in Newfoundland and Labrador. They‚Äôll count your cod, measure them and pass that information along to our scientists for use in future stock assessments. Sarah and Dylan already say it‚Äôs a great summer job. caption_original: Help protect our oceans! We work hard to keep Canada‚Äôs waters and coasts safe and clean through programs and initiatives like the Oceans Protection Plan and Coastal Restoration Fund. But we can‚Äôt do it alone. To encourage the public to get involved, we visit communities with educational materials and take part in school visits and beach clean-ups. Unfortunately, the waters around many Canadian harbours aren‚Äôt as clean as they could be. Recently, our researchers from Newfoundland and Labrador, Corey Morris & Dan Porter, presented results from a survey of 18 harbours over 10 years. During scientific dives, they unexpectedly found, and videotaped, lots of garbage ‚Äì everything from carpet, rubber gloves, rubber boots to appliances like BBQs, stove, even a washer with laundry still inside. Everyone has a role in protecting the ocean and the creatures that live there. Reduce the garbage going into the ocean by recycling, reusing and refusing plastic where you can.

caption_original: We are taking concrete action to protect the endangered North Atlantic Right Whale for future generations. We will be working with partners on a comprehensive approach which includes specific proposals like seasonal speed restrictions to avoid collisions, adjusting fishing gear and testing new gear to reduce the risk of whale entanglements, and working to reduce lost fishing gear in our waters. These strategies were discussed at a roundtable with experts, scientists, Indigenous peoples and representatives from fishing organizations and marine transportation industries in Moncton, New Brunswick yesterday. In addition to the speed restrictions and increased surveillance implemented this past summer, these actions will help us better protect this iconic species. https://t.co/oUilvkXaHj

We will be working with partners on a comprehensive approach which includes specific proposals like seasonal speed restrictions to avoid collisions, adjusting fishing gear and testing new gear to reduce the risk of whale entanglements, and working to reduce lost fishing gear in our waters. These strategies were discussed at a roundtable with eerts, scientists, Indigenous peoples and representatives from fishing organizations and marine transportation industries in Moncton, New Brunswick yesterday. In addition to the speed restrictions and increased surveillance implemented this past summer, these actions will help us better protect this iconic species.

caption_original:
After 12 North Atlantic Right Whale deaths this summer, and with today‚Äôs findings from the Canadian Wildlife Health Cooperative, we must do more to protect right whales for future generations. This report, prepared and released in partnership with the Marine Animal Response Society and Fisheries and Oceans Canada, is the result of many weeks of analysis, research and collaborative work by a devoted team of veterinarians, pathologists and scientists. We thank them for their commitment to this important task. Today‚Äôs findings confirm that the biggest threats to the right whale continue to be vessel strikes and entanglements. Over the next few months, we will meet with partners to plan for changes next summer aimed at helping protect right whales from further harm. http://ow.ly/TdMz30fFsFo 

University of Prince Edward Island

caption_original: The Marine Institute is the first to receive close to $4.7 million to restore eelgrass beds and marine life habitat through the development of artificial reefs. This will help restore migratory corridors for Atlantic salmon and increase ecosystem productivity to support Species At Risk such as the Blue whale and Leatherback sea turtles. This project will benefit this entire ecosystem in Placentia Bay, Newfoundland and Labrador. Congratulations to the Marine Institute! We look forward to our partnership and the good work that lies ahead.  The $75 Million Coastal Restoration Fund, part of Canada‚Äôs Oceans Protection Plan, supports projects that help to restore coastal aquatic habitats. http://ow.ly/jOz130f4b8R

caption_original:
British Columbia‚Äôs Fraser River salmon returns are low this year and conservation is our first priority. After conservation, Indigenous groups have priority access to fish for food, social, and ceremonial uses.  
One of the keys to protecting the future of salmon stocks is effective monitoring and enforcement to detect and deter illegal fishing activity by all user groups. Our Fishery Officers are actively monitoring and enforcing all fishing activity using a variety of methods, including aerial, ocean, river, on-the-ground, night and undercover patrols. Find out more about how we manage Fraser River fisheries to protect salmon: http://ow.ly/vQfb30eJ6uP

caption_original: Aquatic invasive species are among the main threats to the health of the Great Lakes. Asian carp species, including Grass Carp, are considered high risk. We take these threats very seriously, and are committed to responding quickly and effectively. In hopes of preventing additional Grass Carp spawning attempts in the Sandusky River, we‚Äôre working with the Ohio Department of Natural Resources to help capture this invasive species. We sent a crew from the Asian Carp Program with our hybrid electrofishing-netting boat and trammel nets.

caption_original: What can the Beaufort Gyre ‚Äì a unique portion of the Arctic Ocean ‚Äì tell us about the impacts of climate change? A lot! caption_original: Greenland sharks are the only sharks that can tolerate the cold Arctic waters. Most Greenland sharks have a parasite, Ommatokoita elongate, that attaches to their eyes, destroys the tissues, and causes partial to complete blindness. The Greenland shark lives in deep water where there is rarely light, so they mainly use their other senses to get around. We have been tagging Greenland sharks as part of the Tremblay Ecosystem Approach project in Nunavut to track their movement and determine their role in the food web.

Most Greenland sharks have a parasite, Ommatokoita elongate, that attaches to their eyes, destroys the tissues, and causes partial to complete blindness. The Greenland shark lives in deep water where there is rarely light, so they mainly use their other senses to get around. We have been tagging Greenland sharks as part of the Tremblay Ecosystem Approach project in Nunavut to track their movement and determine their role in the food web.

caption_original: Many of the leatherback sea turtles seen in our waters nest in Trinidad and Tobago. Every year, our Sea Turtle Biologist Mike James travels there to work with local conservation groups to collect data from nesting leatherback sea turtles. His work enables remote detecting of turtles on the beach so research can be done throughout the nesting season. Last week, his Trinidad and Tobago colleagues joined him in Halifax to discuss how they can further this collaboration and observe research activities underway off Nova Scotia.

Last week, his Trinidad and Tobago colleagues joined him in Halifax to discuss how they can further this collaboration and observe research activities underway off Nova Scotia.

caption_original: Weighing one and a half tonnes, the Atlantic walrus may look clumsy and slow-moving on land. But in the water, they are smooth and graceful swimmers. They have poor vision but they are still excellent at hunting, using their sensitive whiskers to detect prey and strong suction to swallow them. The Atlantic walrus prefers cold waters and there may still be up to several thousand walruses in Canadian waters. http://ow.ly/UlWs30eJiJt

caption_original:
If you‚Äôre a boater or fisher, it‚Äôs important to learn to identify Asian carp, an aquatic invasive species. 
The term, ‚ÄúAsian carp‚Äù actually refers to four species of carps. Black Carp have a blunt, scaleless head with a small toothless mouth, and no barbels. They have a pointed snout and a slightly downturned mouth. The body is long and narrow and the dorsal fin is shorter than that of Common Carp. Scales are very large with dark edges, giving a cross-hatched appearance. If you think you‚Äôve found a Black Carp, put it on ice (do not freeze) and contact the Invading Species Hotline at: 1-800-563-7711 (in Ontario), or visit http://ow.ly/QoOk30fUGLu

Our scientist, Nathalie Simard, studies aquatic invasive species to protect our waters and the ecosystems, economies, and communities that depend on them. caption_original: Fishery officers in Newfoundland and Labrador monitor the recreational groundfish fishery every year as part of regular fishery patrols. This year, we were pleased to find that once again most participants are keeping conservation in mind and respecting the rules. Of over 1,000 boat inspections, only 44 violations were detected. Two areas where more conservation-minded behaviour is needed are in throwing back fish in hopes of a better catch and going over the daily bag limit.

Tell us about your shark sightings!
We‚Äôre passionate about sharks in Newfoundland and Labrador waters. If you see a shark (even dead on a shore or beach), please put on your ‚Äúcitizen scientist‚Äù hat and help our shark researchers. When you‚Äôre walking on the beach or enjoying a day on the water and you see a shark, record the date, location, estimated length and possible species. Take photos ‚Äì if you can - of its full body length and close-ups of its largest top fin, head or teeth (to confirm species), and underbelly (to confirm sex) to see if 2 male ‚Äúclaspers‚Äù or finger-like projections are there. Send all that information to Carolyn.Miri@dfo-mpo.gc.ca

We‚Äôre in the southern Gulf of St. Lawrence counting fish aboard the Canadian Coast Guard ship Teleost. We‚Äôre working with members of Indigenous organizations and watershed associations in Miramichi New Brunswick to learn how we can better protect the Brook Floater, an at risk freshwater mussel. We‚Äôre training our partners on how to identify the mussels, monitor their health, gather data, and more so we can know more about the species, what it needs, its distribution and how to maintain healthy populations and freshwater systems.

Thank you to the New Brunswick Museum - Mus√©e du Nouveau-Brunswick, Miramichi River Environmental Assessment committee and Anqotum Resource Management for your collaboration!

caption_original: Did you know that the establishment of marine protected areas is one of the measures taken by the Government of Canada to protect and preserve our oceans? Marine protected areas are geographically delimited marine zones that are managed for the purpose of conserving and protecting: marine species ‚Äì including endangered species ‚Äì and their populations; diversity of the ecosystems on which these species depend; representative marine environments; as well as unique locations such as submarine canyons and hydrothermal vents. They can allow certain present and future activities by taking account of their impacts on protected ecological characteristics. To better understand what marine protected areas are: http://ow.ly/NInc30esAzg

They can allow certain present and future activities by taking account of their impacts on protected ecological characteristics. To better understand what marine protected areas are:

caption_original:
Located in the eastern Gasp√© Peninsula in Quebec, the American Bank was selected in 2011 as a potential site for a new Marine Protected Area. In-depth knowledge of the site is an essential prerequisite for creating a Marine Protected Area. We know the site has many assets: diversity of its habitats; presence of many commercially valuable species and species at risk; as well as significant potential as a feeding ground for various species of fish and marine mammals. http://ow.ly/dADN30eoIQY 

The establishment of the American Bank as a Marine Protected Area should promote the productivity and diversity of commercially fished species as well as the recovery of species at risk.

In-depth knowledge of the site is an essential prerequisite for creating a Marine Protected Area. We know the site has many assets: diversity of its habitats; presence of many commercially valuable species and species at risk; as well as significant potential as a feeding ground for various species of fish and marine mammals. The establishment of the American Bank as a Marine Protected Area should promote the productivity and diversity of commercially fished species as well as the recovery of species at risk.

caption_original: If you are a boater or fisher, it‚Äôs important to learn to identify these aquatic invasive species. Bighead Carp have a very large head, a toothless mouth without barbels, and small scales. Their eyes are forward on their head and sit below the mouth. They are solid grey on the back, blending to white below, with dark blotches. If you think you‚Äôve found a Bighead Carp, put it on ice (do not freeze) and contact the Invading Species Hotline at: 1-800-563-7711 (in Ontario), or visit http://ow.ly/ZXnK30fLVLG

caption_original:
Have you ever wondered where the salmon in British Columbia‚Äôs hatcheries come from? First, we capture adult salmon to collect their milt and eggs, which are mixed together to fertilize and then placed in an aquarium to incubate. Once the eggs have hatched, the young salmon are fed in rearing ponds until they‚Äôre ready to be released into local streams. These practices allow our hatcheries to follow the natural life cycle of salmon while they work to improve low salmon stocks.  
Learn more about the Pacific salmon life-cycle here: http://ow.ly/wR1k30himnz

caption_original:
During the Tremblay Ecosystem Approach research season in Nunavut, we‚Äôve been lucky enough to spot bowhead whales. Bowheads can weigh between 75 to 100 tons, reach a length of 18 m, and live up to 100 years; yet, can still manage to launch their massive bodies out of the water! Wow! 

Bowheads filter water through baleen by straining the surface of the water to capture zooplankton, which plays a major role in the ecosystem. Researchers hope to determine from food web studies if the whales come for the food, or perhaps simply for a summer break.
caption_cleaned: During the Tremblay Ecosystem Approach research season in Nunavut, we‚Äôve been lucky enough to spot bowhead whales. Bowheads can weigh between to tons, reach a length of m, and live up to years; yet, can still manage to launch their massive bodies out of the water! Wow! Bowheads filter water through baleen by straining the surface of the water to capture zooplankton, which plays a major role in the ecosystem. Researchers hope to determine from food web studies if the whales come for the food, or perhaps simply for a summer break.

caption_original: We are making navigation safer in British Columbia by investing close to $20 million in hydrographic surveys. This will allow the Canadian Hydrographic Service to collect and share information on water levels, tides, and currents. We will also be able to produce high-resolution charts for mariners. Four B.C. ports have already been surveyed, and nine more will be completed, reducing the risk of accidents. https://t.co/2pbMVufbKR

caption_original: Our Conservation and Protection division adapts its monitoring and enforcement activities to respond to changes in fishing activity or management measures. This year, due to low salmon returns for the island of Newfoundland, the Atlantic salmon fishery changed mid-season to catch and release for the area. Our officers and guardians patrolled and monitored both open and closed rivers during the regular season and after the change to no-retention angling. We inspected 3,901 anglers and found 141 violations, a decrease compared to previous years with no apparent increase in illegal activities during the no-retention portion of the season. Please continue to report all suspicious fishing activities to your local DFO office: http://ow.ly/OJFo30gzAdg or Crime Stoppers.

caption_original: Shark sightings and accidental interactions are common in Newfoundland and Labrador waters and the public plays a vital role in shark research. If you see a shark, dead or alive, take a photo. Note the date and location and send it to Carolyn.Miri@dfo-mpo.gc.ca. But do it safely. No shark selfies! Don‚Äôt bring the shark aboard your boat. Its skin is like sandpaper and the edges of the fins are as sharp as filleting knives. Wear heavy gloves and use bolt cutters to snap off the hook and line. http://ow.ly/VAwz30eJ7UR

caption_original: The ecosystem research team in Tremblay Sound, Nunavut, came across a bird colony! A glaucous gull colony of approximately 25 couples was found on a cliff at the far south of the strait. These birds can nest in different habitats, like cliffs and wetlands. As a result, they have a broad diet. Remains of fish of different sizes and even lemming bones were found, providing a picture of their diet. The cliff offers gull eggs and young birds protection against predators and excellent access to marine resources.

caption_original: Arctic sculpins live in deep and shallow waters where they eat small crustaceans, other small fish and fish larvae. They can tolerate water as cold as -2¬∞C. In order to survive these extreme conditions, they developed a special antifreeze protein to prevent their blood from freezing solid. Sculpins may be a predicator of changes at the bottom of the food web. We collected individuals from two species of sculpins, as part of the ecosystem research project in Tremblay Sound, Nunavut, to better understand their feeding habits, as well as the role they play in the ecosystem.

caption_original:
Learn to identify invasive species! 
Silver Carp is one of four species of invasive Asian carp and is best known for its startled response. You‚Äôve probably seen videos of them leaping as high as three metres above the water‚Äôs surface when disturbed by boat motors or other noise. 
Silver Carp have a large, scaleless head, and a toothless mouth without barbels. Closely related to Bighead Carp, Silver Carp tends to be narrower in shape. They are greyish-black on top and have small, curved scales. They can live up to 20 years!
If you think you‚Äôve found a Silver Carp, put it on ice (do not freeze) and contact the Invading Species Hotline at: 1-800-563-7711 (in Ontario), or visit http://ow.ly/LiTX30gdOcU

caption_original:
The Quagga Mussel is an Aquatic Invasive Species closely related to the invasive Zebra Mussel. The Quagga mussel is found in the southern Great Lakes (lakes Ontario, Michigan, Huron and Erie). Although they have already invaded parts of Ontario, other provinces, like Alberta, Manitoba, and Saskatchewan are working to prevent them from establishing there. If you think you‚Äôve seen or caught a Quagga Mussel:
* Do not release it into the water.
* Collect it and keep it frozen. If you can‚Äôt do that, destroy it.
* Note the location (with GPS coordinates if possible) as well as the observation date.
* Contact Fisheries and Oceans Canada
Click here for more information about this Aquatic Invasive Species: http://ow.ly/e3fV30goji4

For beluga whales, the St. Lawrence Estuary is a critical living environment. This is where they are born, live, eat, and socialize. The St. Lawrence belugas are endangered. Help them recover by behaving responsibly and reducing disturbances. #Beluga400m If you see a beluga whale: Keep your distance, slow down, move at least 400 metres away.

For more information about best practices for navigation around beluga whales: http://ow.ly/UK5q30dMQFg
And about the Regulations in the Saguenay-St. Lawrence Marine Park: http://ow.ly/il8g30dMQJM

caption_original:
Ice delays have the science team working on experimental approaches to tracking and understanding narwhal and their ecosystem in Tremblay Sound, Nunavut. We‚Äôre finding ways to turn tracking studies into community-based research projects. Summer gathering areas like Tremblay Sound are well-known to Inuit, and Inuit researchers are excited by long-term research opportunities.

This week, the team has been working to install a series of Very High Frequency receiving stations in Tremblay Sound. These stations will allow us to follow tagged narwhals and better understand their behaviour. 

Photos: ¬© Troy Neale/Vancouver Aquarium

caption_original: If you are a boater or a fisher, it‚Äôs important to learn to identify invasive species like Grass Carps. Grass Carp have a wide, scaleless head, toothless mouth, no barbels, and a very short snout. They are dark grey with lighter sides (white to yellow) that have a slightly golden shine. Their scales are large with dark edges, and their fins are clear to grey-brown. Adult Grass Carp mostly eat aquatic vegetation. If you think you‚Äôve found a Grass Carp, put it on ice (do not freeze) and contact the Invading Species Hotline at: 1-800-563-7711 (in Ontario), or visit http://ow.ly/sEyG30g4ft4

caption_original: Experts from Fisheries and Oceans Canada and their partners describe for the first time the effects of a "red tide". The neurotoxins contained in the algae that caused the red tide in the St. Lawrence Estuary in 2008 resulted in the death of a large number of fish, birds and marine mammals. The findings of the team of experts provide a better understanding of the causes and effects of this mass mortality and consider actions to be taken to protect ecosystems. Want to know more? http://bit.ly/2tgpkIs

caption_original:
Lieutenant-Commander Dussault joined the Naval Reserve in 1993.  She started her reserve career as a Naval Control of Shipping (NCS) officer, participating in and planning NATO and domestic NCS exercises, and holding various divisional positions at HMCS RADISSON, HMCS DONNACONA, HMCS CARLETON and HMCS CATARAQUI. In 2003, she was appointed Deputy Commander of Naval Cooperation and Guidance for Shipping Unit 2, and then transferred in the same position for Unit 3 to thereafter take command of this unit under Maritime Operational Group 5 in 2007. Since, she re-trained as an Intelligence Officer, has held staff and academic positions at the Toronto Canadian Forces College, and has recently completed a term as Executive Officer of HMCS CARLETON.
 
In 2007-08 she deployed to Kabul, Afghanistan, as the Deputy Commander of the HQ Support Group. During her deployment, she led a support battalion of 400 persons from 40 different countries, looking after the life necessities and security in the NATO Headquarters. During her tour, she completed the rebuilding of an Afghan memorial destroyed by camp construction activity, and led a charity fund raiser for a local orphanage.
 
Her career as a public servant started at Treasury Board Secretariat and Department of Finance. Later, she joined the Department of National Defence, coordinating Army international interoperability programs. Since February 2017 she has joined us as the Manager of Search and Rescue, at the Canadian Coast Guard. 
 
Thank you for your service, Sheyla. 

Veterans Affairs Canada

Today is Navy and Coast Guard Day! On this day, we recognize the important work performed by Canada‚Äôs sailors and celebrate Canada as a maritime nation. Three of our Coast Guard colleagues are being recognized for their contributions to maritime safety and security.

Greg Lick is being recognized for his long-standing career achievements and dedicated service to the Coast Guard. Greg joined the CCG in 1985 as an Engineering Officer Cadet at the Canadian Coast Guard College and is now Director General of Ops of the CCG in the NCR! 

Pamela McLaren, an environmental response specialist in the Central and Artic Region, is being recognized for her work during refloat, recovery and spill response missions in the Arctic and Great Lakes. 

Bruce Marsh is being recognized for his consistent demonstration of outstanding leadership in providing Officer Cadets with an exceptional role model. He continually strives to improve Cadets‚Äô Coast Guard College experience by being a coach and mentor. 

Bravo Zulu to all! 

The Navy League of Canada La Ligue navale du Canada

Monday Motivation!

Dennis Cadieux, Commanding Officer at the Rescue Station in Goderich, ON has 28 years of service with the Coast Guard. Dennis began his career as a cook aboard the CCGS Griffon. Throughout his career, he has worked seasonally as an Assistant Rescue Coordinator, Deckhand, Leading Seaman and ashore as a Regional Operations Officer. After obtaining certification, Dennis Cadieux worked as a Commanding Officer aboard CCGS Vakta and was a Commanding Officer at the Rescue Stations in Tobermory, ON and Amherstburg, ON.

caption_original:
The Canadian Coast Guard, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police and Canadian Pacific Railway paid homage to a true Canadian hero with the unveiling of a commemorative plaque aboard the Canadian Coast Guard Ship Private Robertson V.C. in Burlington Ontario December 10 2017.

Private James Peter Robertson was awarded posthumously the Victoria Cross for his extraordinary valour and devotion to duty while facing a hostile force in one of the most significant battles in World War I, at Passchendaele Belgium.

CP commissioned the plaque at the request of CP engineer Darrel Sundholm of Calgary Alberta. ‚ÄúAfter his family moved from Springhill Nova Scotia to Medicine Hat Alberta, James Peter Robertson joined the Canadian Pacific Railway, working his way up to locomotive engineer. He earned his nickname ‚ÄúSinging Pete‚Äù for his cheerful singing and whistling, whether in the cab or at the roundhouse,‚Äù said Sundholm. ‚ÄúThe bravery that earned him the Victoria Cross made him a legend among locomotive engineers the world over.‚Äù

Steve Pauley, Commanding Officer of the Canadian Coast Guard ship named in Robertson's honour stated at the ceremony ‚ÄúIn this, the 100th year anniversary of his death, it is our honour to share the story of Private Robertson‚Äôs service to our country and remember his ultimate sacrifice with dignity and respect.‚Äù Pauley added ‚ÄúThis plaque will educate all who step aboard this ship for many years to come.‚Äù

CP commissioned the plaque at the request of CP engineer Darrel Sundholm of Calgary Alberta. ‚ÄúAfter his family moved from Springhill Nova Scotia to Medicine Hat Alberta, James Peter Robertson joined the Canadian Pacific Railway, working his way up to locomotive engineer. He earned his nickname ‚ÄúSinging Pete‚Äù for his cheerful singing and whistling, whether in the cab or at the roundhouse,‚Äù said Sundholm. ‚ÄúThe bravery that earned him the Victoria Cross made him a legend among locomotive engineers the world over.‚Äù Steve Pauley, Commanding Officer of the Canadian Coast Guard ship named in Robertson's honour stated at the ceremony ‚ÄúIn this, the th year anniversary of his death, it is our honour to share the story of Private Robertson‚Äôs service to our country and remember his ultimate sacrifice with dignity and respect.‚Äù Pauley added ‚ÄúThis plaque will educate all who step aboard this ship for many years to come.‚Äù

caption_original:
Today we were again on the water east of Salt Spring Island, British Columbia, with partners, participating in day two of a two-day major maritime exercise called ‚ÄúExercise Salish Sea‚Äù. Our Canadian Coast Guard Ship Bartlett stood in for the ferry which was on scene yesterday. Partners practiced working together on marine environmental response techniques.

This two day exercise involved approximately 500 people from more than 20 government and non-governmental organizations ‚Äì including local Indigenous peoples from several Coastal First Nations. A total of 15 vessels and four aircraft were employed. 

Big thanks to everyone who worked with us on both days! Canadian Armed Forces Transport and Infrastructure in Canada BCFerries BC Emergency Health Services, Emergency Management BC, BC Ministry of Environment, Royal Canadian Marine Search and Rescue U.S. Coast Guard Western Canada Marine Response Organization.

Rick Foug√®re grew up in Shediac, New-Brunswick. In 1991, at the age of 20, he enrolled in the Canadian Armed Forces as an Armoured Crewman. 

During his career, he specialized in light armoured reconnaissance with the Royal Canadian Dragoons until 2016. He completed 4 tours in the former Yugoslavia and retired in 2016. After 25 years of service, he transfered to the Coast Guard and is now working as an Incident Command System Officer. 

Thank you for your service, Rick.

Veterans Affairs Canada

caption_original:
In 1997, a team of hydrographers conducted survey work of Allen Bay, aboard CCGS Henry Larsen. They left a time capsule, ashore, beside one of the benchmarks that they used during the survey. It contained a full crew list and a list of the names of the hydrographic team. Byron Briggs, the current Commanding Officer of CCGS Henry Larsen, was part of that 1997 crew list as the Second Officer. The time capsule was later discovered in 2016 by the Bulford family that was hiking in the area. They contacted the Coast Guard shortly after the discovery, to share news of their find. 

In 2017, the Bulfords will complete the last year of deployment in Resolute Bay and wondered if CCGS Henry Larsen was going to be in the area this summer, and if the ship‚Äôs crew wanted to see the time capsule before returning it safely to where it was found before winter set in. A crew change in mid-September of 2017 enabled Captain Briggs to return to the ship, in Resolute Bay, in time to welcome all five Bulford family members onboard the icebreaker.  The time capsule was updated with a 2017 ship‚Äôs crew list and a list of CHS hydrographers. The Bulfords also included the story of how/when they found it. Who knows when it will be ‚Äúrediscovered‚Äù or by who? 

Photo caption: A photographic keepsake of a great visit aboard CCGS Henry Larsen. Captain Byron Briggs and the Bulford family. In purple, young Lily is seen holding the time capsule she discovered in 2016.

caption_original:
Bravo Zulu to the 2017 recipients of the Canadian Coast Guard Exemplary Service Medal in Fredericton, New Brunswick. 

This honour recognizes employees who have completed at least 20 years of service with the Canadian Coast Guard, and have spent 10 of these years working in a position that involves potential risk. These brave and dedicated employees have demonstrated exemplary service through their industrious attitudes, effective work ethics and admirable conduct throughout their careers.

Our ability to ensure the safety of marine traffic would be nearly impossible without our helicopters. 

Roughly 7 million Canadians live in coastal areas, where many people in smaller communities depend of the oceans' resources and tourism to make a living. In order to protect and serve these Canadians, the Coast Guard must rely on its air transportation services to respond to the challenges of this rugged and harsh environment. Learn more: ow.ly/LwwH30groJe

caption_original: Since 2003, the CCGS Louis S. St-Laurent has made an annual mission to the Beaufort Sea to support our Fisheries and Oceans Canada colleagues and their international partners study changing ocean and ice conditions under the Joint Ocean Ice Studies. On last year‚Äôs mission we were lucky enough to have writer Peter Lourie join us on board with Woods Hole Oceanographic Institution (WHOI) where he documented the importance of this month-long expedition. For a more in-depth look at how we support the science done on this mission and what it‚Äôs like to work our largest icebreaker in the Arctic check out his website: https://www.icebreakerstories.com/

caption_original:
Rob Justice joined the Canadian Coast Guard in 2013, following a lengthy career in the Canadian Armed Forces. He enrolled in the Royal Canadian Navy in February 1981. 

Rob served in numerous HMC Ships, in various roles such as Bridge Watch-keeper, Communications Officer, Diving Officer, Air Control Officer, and Combat Officer.  

Rob also served in a number of positions ashore such as Flag Lieutenant to the Commander of the Navy, Fleet Scheduler, Domestic Operations Officer and Deputy Director Operational Test and Evaluation.

After retiring from his last post at the Canadian Joint Operations Command, Rob joined Coast Guard as Manager, Office of Incident Management.  He is responsible for implementing the Incident Command System nationally across Coast Guard.

Thank you for your service, Rob.

Veterans Affairs Canada

Rob also served in a number of positions ashore such as Flag Lieutenant to the Commander of the Navy, Fleet Scheduler, Domestic Operations Officer and Deputy Director Operational Test and Evaluation. After retiring from his last post at the Canadian Joint Operations Command, Rob joined Coast Guard as Manager, Office of Incident Management. He is responsible for implementing the Incident Command System nationally across Coast Guard. Thank you for your service, Rob. Veterans Affairs Canada

caption_original:
In Newfoundland and Labrador the Canadian Coast Guard has 21 light stations with solar charging arrays and battery banks. Two of these stations have hybrid systems that use both wind and solar charging. The hybrid systems are located at Green Island in Fortune Bay and Puffin Island in Bonavista Bay.

A fully operational hybrid system, at a staffed light station, can save approximately 25,000 litres of fuel per year. By using the power of the sun and the wind, we can save from 4,000 to 8,000 litres of fuel annually at each site because fewer helicopter and vessel visits are required.

The Government of Canada is committed to a clean environment and reduced carbon pollution. By utilizing greener power sources, we can help reduce Canada‚Äôs carbon footprint.

A fully operational hybrid system, at a staffed light station, can save approximately ,000 litres of fuel per year. By using the power of the sun and the wind, we can save from ,000 to ,000 litres of fuel annually at each site because fewer helicopter and vessel visits are required. The Government of Canada is committed to a clean environment and reduced carbon pollution. By utilizing greener power sources, we can help reduce Canada‚Äôs carbon footprint.

caption_original: Ann Harvey (1811-1860). Born in Isle aux Morts, Newfoundland, the daughter of a fisherman and the eldest of eight children she often spent time helping her father. While fishing in July 1828, they noticed debris floating in the water, and realized that there was a shipwreck nearby. Ann Harvey, her father, twelve year old brother, and the family dog went out in their boat to locate the wreck, and found a large group of survivors on a tiny island. The family managed to save more than 160 people, and the rescue became famous across province. Ann Harvey became known as the Grace Darling of Newfoundland (from an English woman who participated in a similar rescue). http://ow.ly/Kbt630dblWW
caption_cleaned: Ann Harvey (1811-1860). Born in Isle aux Morts, Newfoundland, the daughter of a fisherman and the eldest of eight children she often spent time helping her father. While fishing in July , they noticed debris floating in the water, and realized that there was a shipwreck nearby. Ann Harvey, her father, twelve year old brother, and the family dog went out in their boat to locate the wreck, and found a large group of survivors on a tiny island. The family managed to save more than people, and the rescue became famous across province. Ann Harvey became known as the Grace Darling of Newfoundland (from an English woman who participated in a similar rescue).

caption_original:
Weeks of planning paid off for the Nunavut Fisheries and Marine Training Consortium, NFMTC, in Iqaluit and the Canadian Coast Guard. Starting with a visit to the NFMTC college by CCGS Henry Larsen‚Äôs Commanding Officer Neil MacDonald, it was followed up by two days of shipboard training and information sharing. 
 
On Wednesday, November 8th, the NFMTC Bridge Watch Rating class was enthusiastically welcomed aboard CCGS Henry Larsen by Captain MacDonald and his crew. A total of 14 students and staff were divided into three groups and sent to various work stations onboard the icebreaker. They learned about anchoring operations and how a windlass works. They were briefed on launching lifeboats during rescue operations; and about the safe operation of deck machinery including mooring and towing winches. As well, they learned how to steer a large vessel while underway as they pulled up the anchor and sailed in Frobisher Bay for a few hours. The enthusiastic and supportive crew were also able to describe shipboard life and share their experiences working with the Coast Guard. 
 
Captain Phil Hillier, NFMTC, noted that for many students, being on board a vessel of this size was a first for most and that being able not only see how the ship operates but also to actually have hands-on experience was very important in supplementing what is taught at the marine college. Captain Hillier was confident that this experience will motivate the students to want to further a career in the marine industry.

caption_original:
After a mandatory safety briefing, on the ground in Iqaluit, #Arctic, Canadian Coast Guard Helicopter 442 , transported a second group of 11 students and two staff from the Nunavut Fisheries and Marine Training Consortium, #NFMTC, to ship from shore, to participate in a day at sea, aboard CCGS Henry Larsen in Frobisher Bay, on Friday, November 10.
 
Following a schedule similar to the one executed earlier in the week, all NFMTC participants were once again engaged by the proud crew in shipboard operations, hands-on training, introduction to engine room machinery and discussions about life on board the ship. This full day of training also included an opportunity for crew to share a meal with the eager students and staff. Of note, CCGS Henry Larsen‚Äôs 1ST Engineer Dan White not only eagerly explained the duties of an engine room officer on watch to the students but also celebrated 35 years of service with Coast Guard that very same day!
 
Captain Peter Richards, NFMTC, expressed in a note to Captain MacDonald afterwards, that the entire class was extremely pleased with the day onboard the ship. He said that the crew did a fantastic job showing the workings of the ship, were informative, engaging and very keen to share their knowledge and experiences. Citing this as an immense learning opportunity, Captain Richards feels this will give the students other career options when considering a future in the marine industry. Bravo Zulu CCGS Henry Larsen! #CCGProud!

#ConsumerAlert: The Competition Bureau is urging consumers to be wary of deceptive tactics used by door-to-door salespeople trying to get you to sign a contract for a new water heater or heating, ventilation and air conditioning (HVAC) system.

These salespeople may misrepresent themselves as your current supplier, a local utility or the municipality when, in fact, they work for private companies that are unaffiliated with your current supplier or any government agency. Many use high-pressure tactics to get into your home, saying that an urgent inspection of your water heater or HVAC system is needed and demanding that you sign a contract with them on the spot. Unfortunately, once you enter into a long-term contract, it‚Äôs too late, leaving you to pay exorbitant cancellation fees to get out of it.

Get tips on how to avoid getting caught in this situation: http://ow.ly/4Ni9302wdjW

caption_original:
Canada‚Äôs Minister of Environment and Climate Change, Catherine McKenna, is hosting an international meeting this week in Montreal focused, in part, on implementing one of the biggest, single, global climate actions ever taken: phasing down hydrofluorocarbons (HFCs). 

We all use HFCs in things like our fridges and air conditioners and they do a great job of cooling us down. Unfortunately, they also warm the planet. Delegates at the Montreal Protocol meeting are working to implement the Kigali Amendment to the Montreal Protocol which calls for a global HFC phase down. Countries adopted the Amendment last year and Canada recently became one of the first countries to ratify it. 

Canada is taking huge steps towards a clean future for our children and grandchildren, and as part of this, urges other countries to ratify the Kigali Amendment.

Countries adopted the Amendment last year and Canada recently became one of the first countries to ratify it. caption_original:
Today is Industry Day at COP23. It reminds us that transitioning to cleaner sources of energy is not only good for the environment,but good for our economy too. 

More and more, renewable sources of energy are becoming cost competitive with traditional sources. We know there are over $20 trillion in new opportunities for investments in emerging markets between now and 2030.

Canadian businesses are well-positioned to seize the opportunities that clean growth presents; resulting in new jobs, new technologies and less pollution. The Government of Canada is investing strategically to support growth across all sectors of the economy.

caption_original:
Today is Health Day at COP23. The Government of Canada is committed to reducing short-lived climate pollutants that are warming the planet and impacting our health, the quality of the air we breathe and the environment.

By using clean technology to reduce short-lived climate pollutants, we will grow the economy and meet our climate change and air quality goals. Cleaner air leads to improved human health, including fewer asthma symptoms, a reduced risk of premature death and fewer heart related issues. http://ow.ly/oIci30gwIds

caption_original: Welcome home, bison!From Elk Island National Park to Banff National Park, the bison are now home again among the mountains. After being absent from the wild for over a century, their homecoming is a historic and cultural triumph.For months, the bison will remain in an enclosed pasture in the Panther Valley, closely monitored by Parks Canada. In approximately June , the herd will be released to elore the full ~1200km2 reintroduction zone in the remote eastern slopes of Banff where they will interact with other native species, forage for food and fulfill their missing role in the ecosystem.

Transport Canada announced new safety rules on March 16, 2017 prohibiting the use of recreational drones higher than 90 m above ground or closer than 75 m from buildings, vehicles, vessels, animals, people/crowds. Anyone who flies a recreational drone these zones could be subject to fines up to $3,000.

caption_original:
When it comes to building bridges we tend to focus on the impacts on local residents during construction and the benefits to travelers once completed. But what about the animals? The new Champlain Bridge is being built with all critters in mind. 

During construction, fish passages will allow finned friends to navigate the jetties in the water where work is taking place. Endangered brown snakes in the vicinity of the project will be relocated to safer homes and new habitat will be created nearby to ensure the snakes can repopulate the area after the work is completed. The new bridge will feature nesting boxes for Peregrine falcons in addition to other protective measures for migratory birds. 

The small area of bird habitat affected by the construction has been well documented and new habitat and nesting sites will be created to compensate for this loss.
caption_cleaned: When it comes to building bridges we tend to focus on the impacts on local residents during construction and the benefits to travelers once completed. But what about the animals? The new Champlain Bridge is being built with all critters in mind. During construction, fish passages will allow finned friends to navigate the jetties in the water where work is taking place. Endangered brown snakes in the vicinity of the project will be relocated to safer homes and new habitat will be created nearby to ensure the snakes can repopulate the area after the work is completed. The new bridge will feature nesting boxes for Peregrine falcons in addition to other protective measures for migratory birds. The small area of bird habitat affected by the construction has been well documented and new habitat and nesting sites will be created to compensate for this loss.

On December 5, Canada became the first country to sign a Technical Arrangement for Maintenance with Japan.  This means that each country:
‚Ä¢ Accepts the aircraft and equipment maintenance safety standards of the other
‚Ä¢ No longer needs to conduct double inspections
‚Ä¢ Will reduce industry costs
‚Ä¢ Will see growth in their aviation industries
Robert Sincennes, of Transport Canada Civil Aviation, and Mitsuo Kawakami, of the Japan Civil Aviation Bureau of the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism, signed the agreement at Transport Canada headquarters in Ottawa.  It will come into effect in February 2018.

This means that each country: ‚Ä¢ Accepts the aircraft and equipment maintenance safety standards of the other ‚Ä¢ No longer needs to conduct double inspections ‚Ä¢ Will reduce industry costs ‚Ä¢ Will see growth in their aviation industries Robert Sincennes, of Transport Canada Civil Aviation, and Mitsuo Kawakami, of the Japan Civil Aviation Bureau of the Ministry of Land, Infrastructure, Transport and Tourism, signed the agreement at Transport Canada headquarters in Ottawa. The Government of Canada today announced $333 million in federal funding for the Finch West Light Rail Transit Project.
The project will include the design and construction of 11 kilometers of light rail transit line along Finch Avenue West. The line will run between Humber College and the new Finch West Subway Station on the Toronto-York Spadina subway extension. 
The project will result in faster commutes over the current bus system, and new economic growth and employment opportunities. It will also improve access to public transit, reduce greenhouse gas emissions, and improve mobility for commuters in the area. http://infc.gc.ca/1927

Throwback Thursday!

In honour of Women‚Äôs History Month, we are paying homage to Esther Marjorie Hill‚Äì Canada‚Äôs first female architect.

Esther graduated from the University of Toronto with a degree in architecture in 1920, becoming the first woman to do so anywhere in Canada. Her passion for design inspired a legacy of projects across the country. 

From the interior design of the former Eaton‚Äôs department store in Toronto, to the conception of the Edmonton public library, to the design of various residential buildings in Victoria, B.C., her extensive resume has diversified Canadian architectural design and paved the way for other women to do the same.

caption_original:
The Arctic Winter Games Arena was built for the 2002 Arctic Winter Games. After the games, the Arena began to fall into disrepair. With federal support, the arena was refurbished making it fully operational once again. The arena proves an outlet for recreational and physical activity in the community and facilitates the growth of many recreational programs, including figure skating, hockey and broomball. 

Having access to such a facility can help inspire Iqaluit's youth to participate in sports, while providing local businesses and artisans with important economic opportunities.

caption_original:
The tide is turning for one of the East Coast‚Äôs most vibrant natural wonders! 

Over the past decades the beautiful Petitcodiac River has been polluted by wastewater runoff and a weakened tidal bore. 

Infrastructure Canada is supporting New Brunswick's ongoing efforts to restore the river to its former glory by constructing a new bridge to realign the causeway, improving the direction and intensity of the water flow underneath. In the neighboring Riverview, Infrastructure Canada is funding upgrades to the TransAqua wastewater facility, adding a secondary level of treatment to ensure cleaner water flows into the Petitcodiac River. 

Learn more about INFC‚Äôs investments in the restoration of the Petitcodiac River:
http://ow.ly/2iZL308caOo
http://ow.ly/EdAz308caSv

Introducing Poseidon, the recently named Floating Foundation Installer (FFI) operating on the new Champlain Bridge worksite.

Montreal youth attending the ‚ÄúFuturs G√©nies‚Äù day camp will have a great story to tell about their holidays when they head back to class! After all it‚Äôs not every day you get to name and build a replica of a massive construction machine.

And the winning name was Poseidon, which fittingly captures the machine‚Äôs impressive strength and important mission ‚Äì placing large pieces of the new Champlain Bridge weighing up to 1,000 tonnes on the floor of the St. Lawrence.

Campers from the science and engineering camp offered through the √âcole de Technologie sup√©rieure, participated in the competition run by Signature on the Saint Lawrence (SSL), the private partner responsible for the New Champlain Bridge Corridor Project and local MP Mark Miller joined SSL to announce the winners.

caption_original:
A smart cities approach aims to achieve meaningful outcomes for residents through data and connected technology.
Why? Because data and connected technology enable: 
‚Ä¢ Openness
When communities make their data truly accessible, usable and barrier-free, their decision-making processes become transparent, empowering citizens and strengthening the relationship between residents and public organizations.
‚Ä¢ Integration
Data and connected technology empower communities to break down silos that exist within local governments and public organizations. 
‚Ä¢ Transferability
When tools and technological approaches are open-source, transparent and standardized, they can be used by communities across the country, no matter their size or capacity. 
‚Ä¢ Collaboration
Connected technology enables communities to bring traditional and non-traditional partners together to collaborate.
caption_cleaned: A smart cities approach aims to achieve meaningful outcomes for residents through data and connected technology. Why? Because data and connected technology enable: ‚Ä¢ Openness When communities make their data truly accessible, usable and barrier-free, their decision-making processes become transparent, empowering citizens and strengthening the relationship between residents and public organizations. ‚Ä¢ Integration Data and connected technology empower communities to break down silos that exist within local governments and public organizations. ‚Ä¢ Transferability When tools and technological approaches are open-source, transparent and standardized, they can be used by communities across the country, no matter their size or capacity. ‚Ä¢ Collaboration Connected technology enables communities to bring traditional and non-traditional partners together to collaborate.

caption_original:
The Canol Trail is known as one of the world‚Äôs most challenging trails. It runs through the Mackenzie Mountains west of Norman Wells, Northwest Territories. The rough terrain includes risks to humans like grizzly bears and fast-moving water. The trail is also a designated contaminated site, due to elements leftover from an old pipeline constructed during the Second World War. 

Recently, a contract was awarded to Englobe Corp. (NWT) to clean up the trail. Remediation of the trail will reduce risks to people, animals and the environment associated with the abandoned pipeline and related infrastructure. This remediation project will benefit the local economy and provide job opportunities to the Sahtu communities. 
To learn more about the Canol Trail Remediation Project, visit: http://ow.ly/r8UJ30fmrCN

Biology students from √âcole St. Patrick High School in Yellowknife, NWT, learned about environmental monitoring from biologists working on the Giant Mine Remediation Project. Students received hands-on experience with the Giant Mine Remediation Project team on how environmental monitoring helps ensure the safety, health and protection of Northerners and the environment. 

While students took samples of invertebrates (small bugs), water, sediment, and small fish for live release from the Yellowknife River, project team members explained how the different types of sampling help evaluate the health of an ecosystem.  The Project team was excited to show students a real-life application of the science they are learning in the classroom.

caption_original: Would you believe these pictures were taken back to back? One of our scientists working at the Eureka Weather Station in Eureka, Nunavut, went for a morning walk. Due to the moon being in its waning phase, the sun and the moon were clearly visible at the same time. The waning moon rises during the night, is visible in the morning, and sets during the day. After capturing this cool shot of a muskox and the moon, she turned around and saw a beautiful sunrise. : Renee Cossitt....

caption_original: Meet wildlife biologist Sabina and wildlife technician Regina. Their work focuses on conserving and protecting seabirds, some of which are at-risk. Recently an apparently injured Northern Fulmar seabird was found on an offshore support vessel near Newfoundland and Labrador. The fulmar features large black eyes and a striking short, tube-like beak and resembles a gull; however it is actually related to the albatross and shearwater. It breeds in a few dozen scattered locations off Alaska and Canada, but is more abundant in the northeast Atlantic. Once the bird was delivered to the Canadian Wildlife Service lab, Sabina and Regina examined it, determined that it wasn‚Äôt injured, and decided it was ready for release. They took it to Witless Bay where a small colony of other fulmars breeds on three islands in the area. They watched the bird drink and vigorously bathe until it swam out of range toward the mouth of the bay. We‚Äôre excited about this happy ending!....

caption_original: Here‚Äôs biologist Kerry, reporting from the field at Last Mountain Lake NWA. While the wildflowers were thriving, this -year-old restoration site needed, and still needs a helping hand. Her plan was to *inter-seed native prairie grasses, and here she was deciding which species and in what amounts. Her team sowed and mowed over the course of the season, and soon there will be a sea of grasses for the birds and wildlife to live in! *Inter- seeding yields a mixture of grasses and legumes/forbs that gives the fullest benefit for wildlife or forage for livestock. It‚Äôs a good way to improve existing stands of single species grasses on fields utilized for pasture, wildlife, or idle land.....

caption_original: Scientists from around agencies and institutes from all over the world are currently working together in the Arctic to measure ice on land and sea. caption_original: We captured this wonderful moment during Canadian Wildlife Service‚Äôs First Annual Mentored Hunt, at Last Mountain Lake National Wildlife Area. Our participants learned so much about ethical and sustainable hunting from our wonderful mentors!With this event, we were able to show people that hunting waterfowl actually helps maintain the population in several ways. Snow Geese, for example, have a current population of over billion. Their nesting grounds are becoming so overpopulated that it is destroying the habitat for other wildlife in the region. Hunting not only helps maintain these populations, but also helps us raise money for conservation, restoration, and enhancement of wildlife habitat in Canada through the purchase of necessary documents such as the Canadian Wildlife Habitat Conservation Stamp.....

caption_original: Arctic goose banding occurs in July and August each year, during a brief period when geese are flightless, while they replace their flight feathers. Individually numbered aluminum leg bands are attached to the birds and they are released. Subsequent encounters from hunters across North America provide information about population size, migration routes and survival of the birds and this information is critical to ensuring the long term sustainability of these species. Here, a banding crew joined force with a helicopter to herd snow geese toward a net for banding on Southampton Island, Nunavut. Garth Ball....

caption_original: Guess what? We built two ‚Äúsupersites‚Äù in Iqaluit and Whitehorse! A supersite has a variety of weather instruments that allow scientists to measure atmospheric conditions in detail. For people living in the North, information like the temperature and humidity isn‚Äôt as important as they are in the South. Knowing about blowing snow and ice-fog (a fog made up of small ice crystals suspended in the air!) are much more relevant! The new sites will help us understand what weather instruments will work best, so that we can improve weather forecasts in the North....

caption_original: It may not look like much but over the last year, scientists have been using these new solar-powered satellite transmitters to tag and track Thayer‚Äôs Gulls from the high arctic to BC. This data is helping scientists learn about the foraging and migrating behavior of this species, and how they overlap with areas of high marine shipping. Recently, a bird with a transmitter stopped moving. The signal remained strong, and coordinates indicated it was located in a remote area of Alaska. Scientists presumed the device lost until a local resident offered to help with the search. Equipped with his boat, GPS, and coordinates provided by ECCC, he found the transmitter on a remote beach off of Iyoukeen Bay ‚Äì km from ! Thanks Mr. Chew!.....

caption_original: ? Citizen scientists play an important role in many of our monitoring programs and provide biologists with invaluable information!While on a recent vacation to Cuba, nature photographer and citizen scientist, Alan Chaplin, did not know the Piping Plover he was snapping photos of was extraordinary. He reported the band only to discover that this bird had outlived its average lifespan by more than times! The -year old plover was spotted near the same location our biologists banded it in . It bred on Cavendish Beach in Prince Edward Island National Park in the early s but had not been reported in over a decade. This resight is extremely useful for our scientists in understanding this at-risk species. Piping Plover continue to be marked in Canada, now with uniquely coded leg flags.

caption_original: Canadian Wildlife Service (CWS) biologist Steve Van Wilgenburg and Wildlife Tech Patrick Turgeon were working over the weekend, attaching automated recorders to trees in Greenwater Provincial Park (SK) to assist CWS monitor boreal forest bird populations. The acoustic recorders intermittently turn on and record the songs of species such as the Threatened Canada Warbler, which can then be identified by trained staff to allow biologists to determine species abundance and distribution. It also helps biologists determine which habitats are used by forest birds. CWS biologists use these recorders to go along with surveys normally conducted by trained staff primarily in the month of June.In March, access to wet areas is easier on snowshoes, and allows biologists to capture data on resident species such as grouse, owls, chickadees and woodpeckers that breed earlier than migrants returning from the tropics.......

caption_original: Josh, Arvids, Andrew and Justin (University of Alberta & York University) arrived in Alert, Nunavut on Wednesday April to take part in one of the largest Arctic eedition ever! They are scheduled to depart from Alert on April. The campaign goal was to visit sites along a few ESA (European Space Agency) CryoSat orbits between Alert and N,150W and perform a full suite of snow and ice measurements at each site. By doing all this, scientists can ensure that ice-thickness maps created from satellite data are correct. Cool right? Photo : Large depth hoar crystals found within the snowpack on sea icePhoto : Justin operating the SnowMicroPen* to take very high resolution measurements of the snow layering.Photo : Cryovex sample team in their twin otter aircraft on route to a sea ice sampling site where they land directly on the ice. *A snow micro-penetrometer, measure the bonding force between snow grains/crystals at very high resolution and quite rapidly!

caption_original: Here we are, four biologists (two in front, one way in the back, and yours truly behind the camera), installing a fence through a small tree-lined wetland at the Last Mountain Lake National Wildlife Area (NWA), Saskatchewan. We need fences like this one to keep our local ‚Äúvegetation managers‚Äù() from wandering off the NWA and onto the roads and neighbouring properties. They munch away to keep our grasslands healthy! It took a lot of elbow grease to install this -km fence. We worked on it in our spare time, over about months, and we had to start bright and early to avoid the blistering summer heat. (Hipwaders are hot at the best of times.) But at least we had the mosquitos to keep us company! - Kerry

caption_original: Meet Anthony Levesque ‚Äì Anthony is from Guadeloupe. He is a dedicated bird biologist with his own birding business now. In the past he was with various agencies in his home country working with hunters and government to implement protection measures for species at critical times of the year to help reduce the impact of hunting on their populations. Shorebirds look completely different in the winter ‚Äì so Anthony is used to identifying them more from their shape and sound than when they are in their breeding plumage in the arctic and are easier to identify. Arctic-breeding shorebirds spend most of their life cycle outside Canada, so it is fantastic when we get to cooperate with our international colleagues. In this photo, the twin otter is loaded up and the survey team is about to head to the tundra!.....

The Agency's enforcement powers are set out in legislation and regulation. These enforcement powers include:

‚Ä¢ ensuring the aircraft are insured and authorized under licence by Transport Canada,
‚Ä¢ verification of flight records, tickets, invoices and other financial records,
‚Ä¢ reviewing airline tariffs to ensure they comply with the licence and the law,
‚Ä¢ ensure that companies have training programs in place to train employees to help persons with disabilities,
‚Ä¢ ensure that advertisers of air fares comply with all-inclusive air price advertising regulations.

For more information about the scope and limits to our enforcement activities, see http://ow.ly/NaYZ30ejT8b

caption_original:
Did you know? We were pioneers of net neutrality...

In 1908, the Board of Railway Commissioners assumed jurisdiction over Canada's early telephone and telegraph toll charges. 

And in 1910, the Board ruled that the CP, which was operating a telegraph news service, was using discriminatory pricing by charging a higher price for delivering messages that originated with other news services. In the telephone industry, a similar principle was used when Bell Telephone, which had a monopoly in a large part of Canada, was prohibited from providing content-based services. 

The Board's ruling established a basic principle of Canadian telecommunications - the separation of control of message content from control of transmission - an early expression of what is now called "net neutrality". 

If you want to know more about our history, check out "At the Heart of Transportation : A moving History" at http://ow.ly/IsZ530dbqS1 #Canada150

In the telephone industry, a similar principle was used when Bell Telephone, which had a monopoly in a large part of Canada, was prohibited from providing content-based services. The Board's ruling established a basic principle of Canadian telecommunications - the separation of control of message content from control of transmission - an early eression of what is now called "net neutrality". caption_original:
"Travel on a plane, train, bus, or ferry is not just a convenience ‚Äì it's an essential part of modern life.  We should move as close as possible to universal accessibility, with individual accommodation as the failsafe, not the default.  We should design for accessibility, build for accessibility, and train staff for accessibility. One in seven Canadians has a disability and this proportion is rising as the population ages, so this is both an ethical and a business imperative."

Scott Streiner speaks to the Accessibility Advisory Council on making Canada's national transportation system the most accessible in the world - from principles to practice. #a11y 

http://ow.ly/8HZG30cEWi0

You can hang up your gloves. We have other ways to resolve disputes.

As a tribunal, we can resolve disputes by making decisions like a court. But we have other dispute resolution tools at our disposal including facilitation and mediation.

For many disputes, we can bring people together through an informal resolution process to resolve an issue easily and to the satisfaction of the parties.

Did you know?
We work with carriers and terminal operators to ensure that accessible travel measures are put into action and maintained within the federal transportation network.
We have made a set of videos called "Accessibility for All". These videos are educational tools to help transportation personnel in providing accessible services to persons with disabilities.  
There are six videos that range in topics from recognizing needs to providing replacement mobility aids to travellers > http://ow.ly/Mf8A307vcVX

caption_original:
Today we released our compliance report on accessible ground transportation at airports. 

The accessible bus, shuttle, taxi and car rental company services are largely accessible at monitored Canadian airports. Of the 23 airports we monitored, 15 airports are fully compliant with the provisions we assessed. All of the remaining airports have committed to becoming fully compliant as contracts with transportation providers are updated. Notable and laudable: most Canadian airports use best practices that go beyond their obligations and demonstrate their commitment to ensuring greater accessibility at their terminals for persons with disabilities. 

For more information, you can read the compliance report at http://ow.ly/9yzM308qvrN

caption_original: Located on a peninsula jutting out into Lake Erie, Point Pelee is not only the southernmost national park in Canada, it‚Äôs the very southern tip of the country itself. Point Pelee is also home to a whopping 66 species at risk ‚Äì more than any other national park in the country. This includes the monarch butterfly, a species threaten by extreme weather and habitat loss. Point Pelee is working to restore the savannah areas that provide vital habitat for the monarch. #LearnAboutButterfliesDay

caption_original: Happy #WorldOceansDay! Let‚Äôs take a moment to appreciate the beauty of Canada‚Äôs oceans. From sea to sea to sea, Parks Canada is committed to protecting and conserving our waters. Watch our video to learn more!
